scenario_name: Fast vs Slow Charging Strategy Optimization
summary: Eight charging strategies comparing 6C fast charge, 1C slow charge, medium-rate blends, leased batteries, and phased upgrades. Constraints cover capacity retention (≥80%), peak utilization (≥0.70), charger ratio (≤1.2), and grid penalties (≤0.15).

notes: Reject because capacity retention falls to 72% (<80%) and battery replacements exceed budget.
Mention accelerated degradation and capex spike despite high revenue.
Regulators want low-noise operations; approve only if operator implements demand-shaping (dynamic pricing plus limited fast-charge pods) to lift effective utilization ≥0.70 before launch.
Decision must spell out the mitigation package rather than flat rejection.
Balanced hybrid meets every constraint (capacity 83%, util 0.76, charger ratio 1.10).
Identify nightly slow-charge recovery as key to longevity.
Condition: add two additional 4C pedestals (≈30k USD) or stagger departures to bring charger ratio ≤1.2.
All other metrics compliant; focus on infrastructure upgrade.
Technical metrics pass, but storage O&M adds 40k USD/year; require a funding plan (tariff adjustment or service fee) to cover the maintenance burden.
Mention solar alignment plus how O&M will be financed.
Reject because ambient temp (38°C) exceeds 35°C limit, capacity drops to 78%, and grid penalty 0.17 > 0.15.
ROI 0.92 < 1 with no signed subsidy; policy board rejects until lease premium drops or revenue support is secured.
Response should cite ROI shortfall and lack of mitigation.
Provide advisory roadmap: recommend charger installation schedule, risk buffer, and when to switch to 4C.
Do not approve; deliver an explanation referencing 7-9 chargers / 6-month buffer.
